docs.snippet: Apple and Google get so much attention that it is easy to forget the power of Microsoft in enterprise computing, which is still by far the biggest part of tech. The new Windows 8 operating system will likely mean we will soon see ultrabooks with t...

headline.main: How Windows 8 Transforms Enterprise Computing

docs.abstract: Apple and Google get so much attention that it is easy to forget the power of Microsoft in enterprise computing, which is still by far the biggest part of tech. The new Windows 8 operating system will likely mean we will soon see ultrabooks with touch screens and keyboards, but also a cloud-based computing model that will drive server sales and promote the use of social software at the office.

docs.snippet: There was good news and bad news this week for Rick Santorum, and his ''Google problem.''     For many years now, Mr. Santorum has been tagged on the Internet by a crude, made-up definition for ''Santorum'' - all part of a scheme devised by the wr...
docs.lead_paragraph: There was good news and bad news this week for Rick Santorum, and his ''Google problem.'' For many years now, Mr. Santorum has been tagged on the Internet by a crude, made-up definition for ''Santorum'' - all part of a scheme devised by the writer and editor Dan Savage to protest Mr. Santorum's comments in 2003 comparing gay sex to ''man on dog'' sex.

headline.main: Haggling Over Definitions: Problem Solved. Sort Of.

docs.abstract: Changes to Google's search algorithm have pushed down search results linking Rick Santorum's surname to a site created by columnist Dan Savage that offers a crude, made-up definition for the word; site was created to protest anti-gay comments by Santorum; top link for Santorum's name is now UrbanDictionary.com, which retains Savage's definition. (M)

docs.snippet: Google started its unified privacy policy on Thursday.     The company has been telling users of its services - search, YouTube, Gmail, Google Maps and Google Docs, among others - that information it collects about users will be compiled in a sing...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google started its unified privacy policy on Thursday. The company has been telling users of its services - search, YouTube, Gmail, Google Maps and Google Docs, among others - that information it collects about users will be compiled in a single dossier for its use.

headline.main: Google's New Data-Sharing, and How to Deflect It

docs.abstract: Google starts unified privacy policy, in which information it collects about users will be compiled in a single dossier for its use; remedies are featured to deflect data sharing with other Google services. (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: 7:17 p.m. | Updated Adding context in fourth paragraph. It's not just Apple. Photos are vulnerable on Android phones, too.

headline.main: Android Phones Can Secretly Copy Photos and Post Them on Web

docs.abstract: Smartphones that run Google's Android system have the capability to secretly copy photos and post them on the Web; by design, Android apps do not need permission to get a user's photos, but it is unclear whether any apps are actually doing this; apps are required to alert users when they want retrieve other kinds of personal data, so the lack of protection for photos comes as a surprise to some experts. Photos (M)h

headline.main: Apple and Google to Meet With Senator Over Privacy

docs.abstract: Senator Charles Schumer said Monday that Apple and Google planned to meet with him to discuss a privacy loophole on smartphones that give apps unfettered access to people's personal photos. On Sunday, Mr. Schumer said that he planned to ask the Federal Trade Commission to investigate Apple and Google after the photo privacy situation came to light.

docs.snippet: On Wednesday, Microsoft demonstrated its new operating system, Windows 8, which is expected later this year. It is a critically important piece of software for Microsoft, which still depends on Windows and Office for most of its revenue.      For ...
docs.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Microsoft demonstrated its new operating system, Windows 8, which is expected later this year. It is a critically important piece of software for Microsoft, which still depends on Windows and Office for most of its revenue. For all the attention given to Apple's iPhone and iPad, or Google's Android OS on phones and tablet computers, Microsoft's lasting market power can still influence how most people think about computing. ''In its time, Windows 95 put the Internet browser in the OS, and that led to widespread communications using computers,'' said Rick Sherlund, an analyst at Nomura securities who has followed Microsoft for years. Windows 8, he said, ''could be a platform shift for enterprises, and for personal productivity.''

headline.main: Windows 8 For Business

docs.abstract: Bits blog notes Microsoft demonstrates its new operating system Windows 8, pointing out it shifts toward more cloud-based interactions. (M)

docs.abstract: When it comes to offering online maps to their users, some companies have been leaving Google Maps and setting out for less familiar territory, Quentin Hardy reports in Tuesday's New York Times. Companies including Foursquare have been moving toward alternatives like OpenStreetMap.

headline.seo: Many Sites Chart a New Course as Google Expands Fees
headline.main: Facing Fees, Some Sites Are Bypassing Google Maps
headline.print_headline: Facing Fees, Some Sites Are Bypassing Google Maps

docs.abstract: Google Maps is the dominant player in the world of street maps, satellite photos and street-level views; its new policy of charging smaller Web sites fees when their users start generating an average of 25,000 map views daily is causing many sites to rebel; 52 million people accessed maps on their smartphones in January, up 67 percent from year earlier.

docs.snippet: SAN FRANCISCO -- When it comes to offering online maps to their users, some companies have been leaving Google Maps and setting out for less familiar territory.      In the seven years since it was introduced, Google's offering of street maps, sat...
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO -- When it comes to offering online maps to their users, some companies have been leaving Google Maps and setting out for less familiar territory. In the seven years since it was introduced, Google's offering of street maps, satellite photos and street-level views has become the dominant player in the world of online mapping, displacing earlier entrants like AOL's MapQuest. According to comScore, 71 percent of the 91.7 million people in the United States who looked at maps online in February used Google Maps.

headline.main: Facing Fees, Some Sites Are Bypassing Google Maps

docs.abstract: Google Maps is the dominant player in the world of street maps, satellite photos and street-level views; its new policy of charging smaller Web sites fees when their users start generating an average of 25,000 map views daily is causing many sites to rebel; 52 million people accessed maps on their smartphones in January, up 67 percent from year earlier. Maps (M)

docs.snippet: Gmail users who cut and paste email messages from the Gmail Web site into text documents for printing may want to try out the optional ''Create a Document'' feature that lets you quickly create a Google Doc from a message.     To turn on the ''Cre...
docs.lead_paragraph: Gmail users who cut and paste email messages from the Gmail Web site into text documents for printing may want to try out the optional ''Create a Document'' feature that lets you quickly create a Google Doc from a message. To turn on the ''Create a Document'' option, log into your Gmail account on the Web. Click the gear icon on the right side of the screen and choose Settings form the menu. On the Setting screen, click on the Labs tab and scroll down the list of Available Labs. Click the Enable button next to ''Create a Document'' and click the Save Change button.

headline.main: Q&A: Tip Of The Week

docs.abstract: Personal Tech Tip of the Week on the Create a Document feature in Gmail. (S)

docs.snippet: Gilad Elbaz of Los Angeles may be the most influential inventor and investor in the booming world of Big Data, where once-unimaginably huge amounts of information are scoured for world-changing discoveries. He sold his company Applied Semantics to...

headline.main: Just the Facts. Yes, All of Them.

docs.abstract: Gilad Elbaz of Los Angeles may be the most influential inventor and investor in the booming world of Big Data, where once-unimaginably huge amounts of information are scoured for world-changing discoveries. He sold his company Applied Semantics to Google; it is the basis of Google's AdSense business, which brings in close to $10 billion in revenue annually. He has interests in 30 start-ups, including an incubator in San Francisco dedicated to Big Data. Meanwhile, his company, Factual, is dedicated to trying to identify every fact in the world.
